Endless Legend is an interesting take on the classic 4X game formula with a gorgeous map, unique factions and hero units. This one is definitely no Civilization clone, it does lots of things very differently. Sometimes these changes are for the better, sometimes they don't work so well.  Combat is one of the clear missteps here. The turn-based combat sounds cool in theory but in practice it is extremely tedious and takes way too long. Auto resolve works most of the time, but will often waste units.  City management is interesting enough, but gets quite heavy on the micromanagement with larger empires. To get the full use out of your cities you need to spend a lot of time reassigning your population.  The game also makes heavy use of RPG elements. Both your heroes and regular units level up and you can equip them with weapons and armor. There's also a fairly in-depth quest system with a long and unique main quest line for each faction.  The Endless games have always had great lore and Endless Legend is no different. The art design and the aesthetic style are top notch too and way ahead of the competition. The UI design isn't quite as strong and sometimes critical information is quite hard to find. The game sorely needs an in-game help system, too.  Personally I would rank Endless Legend somewhere between Civ 4 (probably my favorite game of all time) and Civ 5 (pretty mediocre). On one hand the design is nowhere near as tight as Civ 4 and the balance often feels off. On the other hand Endless Legend does a decent job of introducing new mechanics to the genre without making the same design mistakes Civ 5 did.  The good: - Gorgeous map - Great universe and lore that is also shared with the other games in the Endless series - Unique factions - Lots of interesting quests - Lots of ways to win  The bad: - Game does not feel very balanced - Manual combat takes way too long and gets boring extremely fast, automatic combat works ok but can still waste units - Quite a bit of micro management - No LAN multiplayer  The ugly: - The game could really use an in-game equivalent of Civilopedia - Some quests can be (practically) impossible to complete

The use of provinces keeps the micro-managing down and the tactical combat adds some more depth over the Endless Space fleet battles that used phases and orders. The city expansion mechanic with boroughs iadds some strategic decisions to where you found. The Winter/Summer mechanic is fun and requires you to plan ahead so you can keep the wheels of your empire and armies turning when the snow falls. Minor factions are also fun and can add unique units to your empire.  Each faction plays uniquely adding to replayability. The technology progression uses ages and required numbers of tech from the age to advance, it takes a little bit to get use to in my opinion but it beats Beyond Earths tech-web. There are also faction specific questing victories.  Heros and units are customizable and questing gives it a good high-fantasy flavor.  A great game that will eat your time!

Everything from the way territory is controlled, how cities are built and how factions differ from one another is thought through and presented in an interesting way. (Although Civ 6 has taken a hint and is using a similar city expansion mechanic).  Two of the most interesting aspects of the game are the summer/winter cyce and the aforementioned faction differences. In Endless Legend, the map sometimes shifts from summer to winter, which makes things generally more difficult to survive in for all in the game. The winters are longer and come more frequentlyas the game progresses, showing the planet's slow decline into inhospitability which the game is set against. It's a good way of getting the player to hurry up and plan out how they will advance, since there's a ticking time bomb in the weather.   As for the faction differences, unlike some games, the differences between the factions are rather dramatic, and seriously affect your playstyle. One race cannot research technology properly and so has to steal it from other players, one literally changes form and function depending on the seasons, one can never be at peace and needs to eat living prey (ie enemies) to make up for their bad farming and grow, one faction will only ever have one sprawling megacity but can corrupt the minor factions around the map to work for them and supply troops and resources. That's only a few of them. Amplitude put a lot of care and attention into making every group both visually and functionally unique.  The expansions are fantastic too, each adds something that spices up the game, usually a faction and a mechanic that said faction uses a lot. For example: Shadows included the new espionage system and The Forgotten faction (who need to steal research), whilst Guardians gave all factions access to massive Guardian units, and expanded on the in game quests system to include shared quests and races to complete certain objectives for rewards.

tl;dr: This game is great. Get it.  Endless Legend is a turn based strategy game that takes the best elements of classic series such as Heroes of Might and Magic and Civilization, and combines them to create a product that is greater than the sum of its parts.  The core of the game is to build your empire as one of several extremely unique factions. There are the Broken Lords, beings that inhabit suits of armor and subsist entirely on Dust, the game's equivalent of gold, bypassing the need for food entirely. Or there are the Necrophages, a sentient insect race that devour everything in their path, including their own citizens if they desire. There is a faction that controls the world markets and cannot declare war, and a faction that values diplomacy and can force peace treaties and alliances. These are just a sample of the factions, and each one brings with it an entirely unique strategy.  Much like the Civilization series, players have an option for how they would like to pursue victory. In addition to staples like Domination or Scientific victories, there are also more unique victory methods such as the Expansion victory where the goal is to control over 70% of the territories on the map. There is even a storyline victory, in which players can race to unlock the secrets of their faction and the world of Auriga as a whole.  Developing territory in this game is incredibly satisfying as well. Each region in the game can only be occupied by one city, and the owner of that city becomes the owner of that territory, thereby gaining control of any resources that territory may hold. Developing cities is much more interesting than just building a bunch of buildings as well. Players can expand the amount of tiles their city exploits by actually building expansion districts that visibly increase the size of their city, in addition to providing increased resource generation.  Combat is a unique affair where both sides battle for six turns. Units and generals can be outfitted with an assortment of different gear types that affect everything from their damge and defense, to providing unique abilities such as retaliating against everything around the unit. The battles play out automatically with some strategical assistance from the player. If the battles aren't decided within the six turns, they are considered a draw.  One the biggest hurdles to overcome when playing Endless Legend is the UI. While extremely informative and clean, it provides a lot of information that can be daunting to newer players. My recommendation is to take time to complete the tutorials provided in game, as they cover all of the basics and really help familiarize players with the UI as well.  If you enjoy 4x and turn based strategy games, you owe it to yourself to give this game a shot. The base game is a great price, and frequently goes on sale, and the expansions only serve to improve the experience.

For nearly 30 hours, I have tried repeatedly to find the 'hook' for this game and I look back at 30 hours spent banging my head into a wall in an attempt to squeeze some sort of enjoyment out of this game without success.  The game is gorgeous, the audio is nice, the lore is engaging, the UI is *mostly* efficient and intuitive but ultimately the mechanics feel awkward and grossly unintuitive. I feel that many changes were introduced into the typical 4x formula more out of a desire for novelty than genuine improvement over tried-and-true systems. It's not praise when I state that every time I put this game aside for a month or two and come back to it that I am nearly at a complete loss as to how to play/enjoy the damned thing.  Part of the allure of a strategy game is in untangling its mass of interconnected parts and learning a new series of mechanics and how they affect each other and the overall thrust of the game but I feel that the awkward learning curve of Endless Legend lacks the payoff in gameplay that makes the effort feel worthwhile. Most of the mechanics revolve around maximizing an endless pile of tiny modifiers that work invisibly most of the time and don't really contribute to an impression of growing an empire. The spreadsheet-y nature of 4x games is just too front-and-center for this one and in board game terms, I feel like I'm playing a euro-style abstract victory-point chase rather than a more viceral, thematic war game.   I am not baffled by the popularity of this game and can see how it would be very appealling with gamers of a different stripe than myself but for me, the only reason that I keep coming back to the game and giving it another go is that I am chasing after the same enjoyment (and failing to find it).

First let me say that I don't think this is a bad game. Its very polished, looks great, the menus are intuitive, and its easy to get an understanding of what your empire is doing in a quick look.  However, this game bored the ever living ♥♥♥♥ out of me.  My biggest problem was the combat. I read reviews and from what I understood, combat was going to be like Age of Wonders 3. And while they share similarities, Endless Legend dumbed it down big time. In this game, you don't individually move your units and attack. Instead, you give a very, VERY general set of instructions. You tell a unit to attack an enemy, no matter if the unit can reach the enemy or not, and thats it. Your unit does its best to get within range and attacks if able. Automatically. There is no tactics, no skill. Its purely who has the most units, who has the smartest units, and who has the best equiped units.  No special powers, no tactical positioning to flank an enemy cause there is no bonus for such things. You can't select one unit, move it out of the way so another unit can move to its spot and attack. You can't even really tell your unit where to go in most cases. While it is true that you can tell your unit to move to a specific place next to an enemy and attack, if that enemy moves before that unit, the unit isn't going to do anything except move because now the enemy isn't where you told your unit to move.  Combat in this game has been dumbed down to 'Everyone attack this one guy! And if he dies, then attack whatever guy you feel like! But be sure to trip over yourselves trying to get within fighting range!' You make sure the red lines are all pointing towards one guy, hit play, and watch your units try their little hearts out to attack whatever the red line pointed at.  My next issue is equiping and upgrading your units (I.E. the RPG aspect of this game)  First, I have an issue with having only one infantry, archer/support, and calvery unit per race. In order to get more units, you have to convince a minor faction (Either by destroying their village in your region then rebuilding it, bribing them, or completing a quest for them) to be assimilated into your faction. Then you get their one unit. Which I must admit, was pretty lame to me. I like to have multiple units with different abilities so being restricted to less than a hands count sucked.  I was fully expecting to find magical gear like powered up swords or armor and having to choose which units or heroes to give it to. Instead Endless Legend makes you choose between having your one racial infantry unit hold a sword or spear (Doing extra damage to infantry or calvary respectively) and just getting the next 'Tier' of armor your technology level allows.  I will admit, I liked being able to upgrade or 'Retrofit' as the game calls it my units after adding my newly researched better armor to them immediately. But again, the upgrade itself is nothing more than equiping the next level of equipment rather than making any real choice as to how to upgrade them.  The heroes was something I liked however. Your heroes have a skill tree with 3 different trees with abilities that can affect them if they are the general of an army or the mayor of a town. Or both in some cases. It did make you have to choose if you wanted a powerful unit or to give a city huge bonuses.  The city building was interesting. Its a mix between Civilization and Heroes of Might and Magic 6 I believe. Maybe 5. I don't remember. But you build a city anywhere you want in a region, which are randomly cut out areas on the map. But you can only have one city per region so once you build a city, that region is considered yours. Along with everything in it. So enemy players can't build a city directly next to your land and take it via influence like in Civilization.  I'm not a real fan of the thumbs up or down method steam uses to rate games because this game itself isn't bad. It was just incredibly boring to me which is why I cannot recommend it.

For those on the fence:  --I would not recommend this game unless you are new to a 4X title or are a fan of Endless Space. What follows is a critical review of a game I honestly wanted to enjoy (ergo, I bought it).  This game is not one of tactical battles, but of empire-building. It most closely resembles Civ5, but with a few minor differences:  +This game allows you to equip commander/governors and further shape your empire's bonuses. +It also has you building small armies of units, vice each being its own hex.  -On the downside, combat is resolved in a horrible fashion, with only initial choices being made as to where to place your units, what 'stance' they should take, and then who they should attack (if able). There is rarely any reason to not just attack one enemy at time, and you are largely a spectator once combat begins. Not being able to issue 'true' move commands during a battle greatly hampers the experience and actually yields a system that is even less engaging than Civ5 (a game that is combat-lite to begin with). This is not a Gettysburg simulation, so abstraction in orders does not fit and simply comes off as over-simplification.  -UI is somewhat cumbersome, with right-clicks backing you out of menus at times and other times expanding information. Getting heroes transferred between governor and commander requires creating and army, then shifting the hero the university, then shifting them to the army. Should have been one button (maybe I missed something). Other items are similarly hidden and I would recommend YouTubing Tokshen's channel to see a decent LP of it first to get a handle on things. -You have to research diplomatic processes such as parley and bribe, as if they were tech rather than natural extensions of logic. -There are only two seasons: Winter and Summer. Would be interesting if expanded on, but just results in shifting population around to make the most of it. Lack of a Spring or Fall makes it seem random and gamey. -Artificial time mechanics. I hate 'timers' in games, and this one has the seasonal, the Empire planning (every 30 turns), and technology tiers instead of trees. Ended up clicking through many turns to heal units, pass the winter, or wait for unneccessary techs to complete to get what I really needed.  -No world-map or commander skills to use to change things up. Most 'fantasy' stylings have magic or leader skills, this one has nothing. Ends up feeling stale and predictable.  On the bright side: +No crashes during play. +Multiplayer was smooth with no issues connecting over Steam via invites. +Simultaneous turns means less down-time waiting for the CPU to process its moves in between and a quicker game overall. +The game is aesthetically pleasing (looks sharp) and resources 'pop' out when you can utilize them, but blend in well when not available.  +Races play quite differently in the sense of what is available and when (Drakken have diplomacy, Flyers have tech, etc), as well as how resources are utilized. Again, most of this happens on the strategic level, but is well themed.  Overall, this game doesn't do anything new and that which it does, has been done better elsewhere. If you must have a fantasy variant, I would recommend Dominions 4, Eador, or Age of Wonders instead (in that order). If you already own those and just want something new, go ahead and give it a try. Similar to Endless Space, it seems these devs don't know how to do combat, just focusing on trying to reinvent the wheels of research and expansion without truly improving them. Awkward is the best description.

I know this game is well-regarded and I purchased it based on high user and critical reviews, but I'm fairly disappointed. A lot of aspects of this simulation are very good - it's not that it doesn't have redeeming qualities. It is, however, a buggy game that confuses pedantry for detail. In particular, the combat system is very, very poor and onerous. Most of the time you'll simply speed up the animation and put it on auto. For a game often touted as a grown up version of Civilzation V, I expected a lot more.   Maybe it gets better if you spend hundreds of hours playing it. I don't think that it's worth it, for that kind of time investment you could be playing EUIV or CK2, and if you did want to keep your job and family you could just play Civilization V instead. The combat and unit placing make little to no sense - for example, you can be in a relatively open area next to an ocean, and if you approach an opponent from a certain tile, only two of his eight units will appear. Since the combat has a hilariously arbitrary 6 turn limit before both sides shake hands and decide to break for tea, this can be an issue if you need to destroy an army racing somewhere important (usually either trying to take a city or trying to escape). You'll often see this happen with minor factions that have 3 or more units built up. You'll get a lonely giant, rather than 3 buddies, and you'll just kill them over 3 times.   The unit 'design' system is well intended but often bogs you down. Part of the problem is that when you want to variations of a unit, you can't amalgamate the design at a later date. You might end up with an army with, say, 8 identical units, but they require you to make three different designs for the same unit. For example, if you slap on an accessory that gives your infantry disease immunity because you're fighting bugs on one side of the map, when you bring those anti-bug units over you can't just have them pick up the next infantry upgrade the rest of your army is using.  The tech/city-sim aspect of the game is neat. All and all this has to be the most wildly overrated game on Steam, in part a reflection of the strong desire for a more combat heavy / fiction version of Civilization (which Beyond Earth failed to provide, and I suppose one can say that Endless Legend is at the very least better than Beyond Earth).  I have to say the combat in this game is a flaming train wreck, however. As simplistic as it is in Civilization, it's more sensical and building an army doesn't feel like an awful chore. If you're really into sims, then you'll probably like Endless Legend. Otherwise, stick to Civilization V, and again, if you really want something meaty and time consuming, the Paradox fare is more appetizing.

Don't believe the hype: this is a fairly terrible entry in the 4x genre. The developers have provided a single innovation: a new way to provide bonuses for the AI. This 'innovation' prevents the player from fully controlling his units during a battle, which leads to incredibly sub-optimal unit maneuvers. Attack orders are issued at the beginning of each round for all units, so if your unit's target dies during the round, the unit will choose its own battle plan, which is invariably awful. Rather than attack a nearby unit, yours will pick an absurdly distant one and have to walk around the absurdly common obstructions that litter every battlefield. This phenomenon is most noticeable and insufferable when playing a faction with slow moving 3rd tier infantry against an AI faction with flyers: the opposing flyers will isntantly relocate next to your squishies while your titanic morons ping pong across the battlefield.  As for the 'changing world' that everyone keeps talking about: you will experience the occassional winter, which slows movement and all types of production. Yeah....uh...amazing...or something.   For a fantasy 4x, this game is terribly light on magic, which is disappointing since magic typically provides the tactical variations in these games. Any 'spells' your units have are little more than auto-attack or auto-defend animations.  Your roster of troops is limited to 3 units plus various mercenaries. The units you do have are typically uninteresting with little in the way of tactical options. Attack or defend, that's it. Oh, the choices!  Perhaps this developer will soon make an audacious foray into another genre by providing us 'Endless' tic tac toe bereft of the Xes.

Or you might be asked to raise the level of your home city or district when the game makes absolutely no other mention of how to do that (it means build a burough surrounded by 4 other burroughs, but good luck figuring that out). The turns themselves are interminable. The AIs sit and think for so long that you will probably find yourself spending the majority of your time just waiting for the end of turn calculations. So, short version: A beautiful, interesting game whose frustrations unfortunately outweight the fun.

I LOVE the game itself, BUT: The multiplayer is BROKEN!  The game is simply pathetically bad written and incomplete! It's a multiplayer game - with broken multiplayer functionality through and through. You won't even be able to play 2 games completely in a row, because loading doesn't work over 90% of the time (that is no joke, google it!)  Just google it - 'Endless Legend Multiplayer Load'  It's nearly impossible (and I'm not kidding!) to resume a game. You can either leave the computer running 3 days with the game in the background until you have completed it with your friends, or you can exit the game, no need to save it, as you can (to over 90%) NEVER RESUME IT.  If you can somehow load the game (try it over 10 times and you might get lucky) here are the following things that usually happen:  1. Out of sync (you all see different things happening - just exit) 2. Exception and the game crashes when you hit 'continue' after the message 3. The savegame is loaded wrong (no joke) and you are missing units, reasearch, diplomatic stats, ... - you even have things you never built or reserched, it's just a broken savegame 4. The 'synced icon' (yes, that's right - the game has a symbol FOR WHEN IT WORKS) is always black and one turn after you resume the game, it crashes or goes 'unsync' and then crashes.   The game will in all likelihood be the worst written game you have ever and will ever see. And I have played games which needed a patch to run in the first place! Even C&C KW which most regard as the worst written strategy multiplayer (you finish about 70% of all games since it randomly tells you someone was using a wrong/illegal game version).  But this is still nowhere close to Endless Legend. It's like an alpha version when it comes to multiplayer. Considering the problems are known for over 2 years now and they bring out addons other patches and fixes and stuff, but still haven't fixed the multiplayer, I guess the code is just so badly written and unmaintainable that the time needed to fix the multiplayer issues just isn't worth investing anymore... (Happens more often than you might think with game code).  For me - a strategy games needs a (working) multiplayer, especially a 4X. It's awesome solo, but still loads better with friends.  I really hope that they will finally fix the multiplayer problem in Endless Space 2, in which case it'll surely be an awesome game through and through!

Every fantasy 4X game should be compared to the 1994 classic  Master of Magic . Complete review, as always, found on blog @ amenglishDOTweeblyDOTcom/endless-legend   This is a perfect game to showcase how pathetic the 'yes vs no' recommend system is- that and 'Banished' and 'PoE' and 'Banner Saga' and... Why?  At $40, $50, or even $50+ this game is grossly, GROOOOOOSSSSSLLLLY overpriced. If this game was free and/or you early access supported this game (or ones like it) for $15 and got a free copy of the game would you say your $15 was well spent? Hell yes.   The problem? More and more and more games are going early access + kickstarter route and what this means is that many people will be getting a game that sells for $50+ at retail and they will get it for less than half that price. What this creates is a large, sometimes unbearably large group of 'day one players' who basically are playing a game that cost them next to nothing (Sometimes as little as $5). So what do they expect when playing the game? I suppose at $5 you expect the game to start and allows you to actually play, and that is about it- so anything else you basically splat in your pants.   Is Endless Legend bad? No... Is Endless Legend worth more than $20? Hell to the no... HELLLLLL NOOOO!  In a genre as super saturated as the 4x is, in fact next to FPS and 'RPG's' the 4x genre might be the largest, this is not a genre that you have to 'dig deep' to find 4x games that are amazing and that are half the price or even a quarter of the price. On a price entry point alone this game is terrible, let alone if this is your first 4x game. However, if you have played EVERY SINGLE 4x game out there and LOVE them all, get this game on sale ($20) and you shouldn't be too dissapointed.   If this is your first 4x game purchase let me STRONGLY recommend you turn around and walk away. Why? This is the type of 4x game that will require those familiar with 4x games about 10-30 hours of gameplay before they even get a strong grasp of everything in the game- for those new to the genre this game will most likely make you swear a blood oath never to purchase another 4x game again- which is unfair to a very fun genre.  If you are new to the genre may I suggest two games, Civilization Revolution and Age of Wonders. Both are great entry points, both are amazing as far as price, but one is more for people who like 'realistic worlds' (Civilization) and the other is more 'fantasy/RPG' (Age of Wonders).   If you are still interested in buying this game here is a small section of my complete review that sums up who would actually like this game:  By “having hours and hours to learn the game” I really mean at least 25 hours to even grasp what is going on. You will play the HORRIBLE tutorial and come out of it with your eyes swollen, it will be like drinking from a fire hydrant, and then you go play the game on normal and get torn to pieces- even if you are familiar with 4x games. 10+ hours later you try your next play through, you know more now but you still damper back the difficulty and decide to only do auto-battles this go around. If you are lucky this time you will figure out that there really isn’t 10 different ways to win the game, there is only one way to win the game- exploiting the AI and attacking the entire game. You want to play this game like any other 4x game- build wide or build tall- you will eventually get overwhelmed every time by an enemy army that is all lv 10 across the board. You see, attacking non-stop you build an army of lv 5-10+ troops which by the end of the game will and can destroy 60+ enemy units without taking a single point of damage and the same time the AI will not invade and attack your unguarded cities if you are in their lands attacking them. So what you do is decide to play again with this tactic in mind and play on normal; you absolutely destroy the game and it is so ridiculously easy you wonder if you just didn’t understand the game before. So you play again on normal but change tactics, maybe even factions (the dragons and dust knights are both ridiculously easy) and watch once again as you get destroyed. So at this point in time you have plugged in close to 50 hours of game play and you finally understand the game, but how much fun is it? Each and every play through from this point on (even on harder difficulties) will be exactly the same, even the same quests, and you will really only be able to play with one playstyle as the others will just lose out every, single, time. So bottom line in this regard is that if you don’t like aggressive playstyle (it is 500x easier to just take over an enemy city than it is to build a settler and build your own city) and don’t have hours upon hours to actually understand the game, even if you love 4x games this game will not be enjoyable.
